urn:contentItem:5X6C-43K1-F03R-N0DS-00000-00Jeff Reeves's Strength in Numbers: Get into China stocks now before a relief rally begins2019-10-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:00ZLexisNexisJeff Reeves's Strength in Numbers: Get into China stocks now before a relief rally beginsfpwire

Oct 04, 2019( Financial Press: https://financialpress.com/ Delivered by Newstex) There are plenty of reasons for investors to freak out when they see the word 'China' in a headline. Amid the simmering trade war, which has seemed to benefit nobody other than import/export consultants[1], the looming holiday shopping season presents problems over how manufacturers and consumers could be hurt. And to make matters worse, remarks from President Trump[2] about limiting investment in the region or even delisting Chinese stocks altogether has sparked uncertainty into how to manage exposure to the region. But investors should take a deep breath before they buy into the panic.

Just as the doom-and-gloom crowd hasn't managed to sink the U.S. stock market yet in 2019, with the S...00 Index SPX, 0.80%[3] still sitting on a year-to-date return of about 15% through Thursday's closing bell, neither have the bears been able to gain traction in China. In fact, the Shanghai Composite SHCOMP, -0.92%[4] has actually slightly outperformed the S...00 this year. There are always risks in every investment, and you won't find a single region in the world where all the analysts are bullish. But in many ways, the negativity around China may be setting up investors for a nice relief rally if and when the gloomy trade environment clears. If you're afraid of China, here are five big reasons to reconsider — and a bunch of trading ideas to gain exposure to the region:The case for ChinaAside from day-to-day gyrations based on tweets, commodity prices or economic reports, there are a few bigger points worth making about investments in China: You can't avoid it: China's national economy is the second largest on the planet, behind only the United States. But perhaps more importantly, its national stock market is also No. 2 behind the U.S. when measured by market capitalization. Beyond names most investors are familiar with, including massive state-run energy firm Sinopec SHI, 0.17%[5], there are also a host of smaller firms that are among the 1,500 or so 'A shares' listed on the Shanghai stock exchange, and another 1,400 stocks listed onshore on the Shenzhen exchange. That means blanket statements like 'China stocks are too risky' are actually more like saying 'the stock market is too risky.' If you think that way, be my guest and attempt to time the market or hide out in an all-cash portfolio. But if you believe in diversified investing for the long term, then China must be part of your portfolio. Still growing: Yes, in 2019 China GDP growth will likely hit the lowest level in nearly three decades. But let's remember that growth rate is still forecast to be 6% to 6.5%, comfortably double that of the U.S. and multiples of other economies including Japan's. As an investor, it is proper to worry about recent trends and near-future expectations. But just as quibbling over what kind multiple is 'fair' for a tech stock sometimes can overshadow the long-term growth story, it's important to remember that the underlying fundamentals here. Opening up: China is only getting bigger, too. Recent trade challenges with the U.S. aside, it's important to keep in mind the general opening of China's economy over the past several years. Consider a big change to ownership restrictions[6] in the financial sector, announced this summer in the thick of tariff talks, which is set to take effect in 2020, a year earlier than previously planned. Also this summer, a highly anticipated stock connection between London and Shanghai created a direct link to Western investors in place of previous efforts routed through Hong Kong. Benchmarks adding China: On a related topic, this opening up means that structural challenges limiting institutional investors are falling away. For instance, in 2018 it was announced that the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index would start to phase in Chinese debt[7] across the next few years. And in regards to equities, leading stock index provider MSCI added more than 230 mainland China stocks to a flagship emerging market benchmark. (Relative) political certainty: Perhaps the most ironic of all arguments for China investing is that investors may have the most visibility into the politics and policies of this region next year vs. any other major market in the world. The U.K. was already a bit of a mess thanks to Brexit drama, but is even more uncertain after the recent antics of Boris Johnson. And as a result, the European Union's relationship with the rest of the world has been thrown in to question, even as EU politics have been disrupted by a major European Parliament election in May that brought in new leadership as part of a new five-year legislative cycle. And let's not even talk about impeachment and what the 2020 U.S. election holds. If you're looking for political stability and a long-term vision, China's tradition of crafting 'five-year plans' for its economy is a breath of fresh air. What's the China trade?If you want broad China exposure, unsurprisingly there are a bunch of ETFs for that. The iShares China Large-Cap ETF FXI, 1.61%[8] is the largest by assets, with some $4.7 billion under management, and provides easy access to 50 of the largest publicly traded corporations in China. IShares also has the No. 2 fund via the iShares MSCI China ETF MCHI, 1.76%[9], a 43.6 billion fund with a deeper bench of roughly 470 China corporations. These are the most obvious and liquid options, but certainly not the only ones. For those particularly bullish on Chinese technology stocks as the economy transitions away from its old manufacturing dominance and into a digital age, the KraneShares CSI China Internet ETF KWEB, 2.21%[10] is worth a look. Though not sponsored by a big ETF shop, the KraneShares fund is definitely legitimate with more than a million shares traded daily and nearly $1.5 billion in total assets. Holdings for this fund are focused, with a list of only about 40 stocks, but the lineup avoids the sprawling state-run financial and energy stocks that can be big parts of other ETFs in this region. If you're a stock-picker, then conversation about China is less about general opportunities and sentiment and more about individual companies with a uniquely bullish outlook. And just like Big Tech in the U.S., China's technology giants including Alibaba Group Holdings BABA, 2.24%[11] and Tencent Holdings TCEHY, 1.44%[12] are worth your attention because of their scale and entrenched operations in fast-growing areas including cloud computing and e-commerce. If you worry about chasing growth in the region, however, there are still plenty of value-oriented plays in China that are looking increasingly attractive. Take telecom behemoth China Mobile Limited CHL, 1.76%[13], which boasts a staggering 925 million wireless customers, more than double the entire population of the United States. It has a forward price-to-earnings ratio of about 10, compared with U.S. telecom giant Verizon's VZ, 0.17%[14] 12. Throw in CHL's 4.7% dividend yield, which tops the 4.2% offered by Verizon, and income investors may want to consider this China telecom over domestic options. And while not as obvious, it's important to note that growing interconnectedness means that China plays don't have to be headquartered in the nation. Case in point: Aerospace giant Boeing BA, 1.28%[15], which is incredibly dependent on Chinese aircraft sales and books more than 13% of total revenue in the region. Or better yet, look at Apple AAPL, 0.85%[16], which booked 17% of total revenue in Greater China last quarter. Obviously how these companies manage their strategy matters just as much as mere exposure to the region. However, they also illustrate how major U.S. stocks may in fact be indirect ways to capitalize on China. Jeff Reeves is a MarketWatch columnist. urn:contentItem:5S2W-RV01-JDPT-T3TC-00000-00JEFFREY ARNOLD, CEO, SHARECARE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION2018-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:00ZLexisNexisJEFFREY ARNOLD, CEO, SHARECARE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

April 9, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

JEFFREY ARNOLD, CEO, SHARECARE

WESTIN: Technology has become a driving force that is changing the health care area. Sharecare was developed to create a secure place for patients to feel in control of their health and to connect with their doctors.

Since its founding in 2010 Sharecare has raised a total of $350 million in three rounds of financing, partnering with a diverse group of strategic investors including media companies like Discovery Communications, Harpo Productions that's Oprah for those of you who don't know, and First Co Corporation. We welcome now the chairman and co-founder and CEO of Sharecare, Jeff Arnold. So, Jeff, welcome. It's good to have you in Bloomberg.

ARNOLD: Thank you.

WESTIN: And you know this area so well because among others, you were actually were co-founder of WebMD as well, so that we all know about it.

ARNOLD: Yes.

WESTIN: Explain to us what exactly is going on as tech meets health care right now? What's the transformation we're watching?

ARNOLD: Well, I think even 20 years ago when we started WebMD, we thought health need a home page. There needed to be a destination where doctors and patients could go that wasn't so fragmented. Back then, just getting help information not from your doctor was a big deal. But with all these other industries being disrupted, hospitality, transportation, financial services, smart phones being so pervasive now, why can't health care be next?

And so this idea of all of your health in one place where all the various stakeholders are coming together, health plans, providers, large employers to empower consumers, to take control of their health, to reduce health care cost is I think the timing is now.

WESTIN: Jeff, we've been hearing about this for some time. And it certainly makes good sense if you won't be keeping scraps of paper and big files. And yet we don't seem to be getting there. What's the resistance? What's between us and really having an electronic way to access our health care data?

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JEFFREY ARNOLD, CEO, SHARECARE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

APRIL 09, 2018

SPEAKERS: JEFFREY ARNOLD, CEO, SHARECARE

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Technology has become a driving force that is changing the health care area. Sharecare was developed to create a secure place for patients to feel in control of their health and to connect with their doctors.

Since its founding in 2010 Sharecare has raised a total of $350 million in three rounds of financing, partnering with a diverse group of strategic investors including media companies like Discovery Communications, Harpo Productions that's Oprah for those of you who don't know, and First Co Corporation. We welcome now the chairman and co-founder and CEO of Sharecare, Jeff Arnold. So, Jeff, welcome. It's good to have you in Bloomberg.

JEFFREY ARNOLD, CEO, SHARECARE: Thank you.

WESTIN: And you know this area so well because among others, you were actually were co-founder of WebMD as well, so that we all know about it.

ARNOLD: Yes.

WESTIN: Explain to us what exactly is going on as tech meets health care right now? What's the transformation we're watching?

ARNOLD: Well, I think even 20 years ago when we started WebMD, we thought health need a home page. There needed to be a destination where doctors and patients could go that wasn't so fragmented. Back then, just getting help information not from your doctor was a big deal. But with all these other industries being disrupted, hospitality, transportation, financial services, smart phones being so pervasive now, why can't health care be next?

And so this idea of all of your health in one place where all the various stakeholders are coming together, health plans, providers, large employers to empower consumers, to take control of their health, to reduce health care cost is I think the timing is now.

WESTIN: Jeff, we've been hearing about this for some time. And it certainly makes good sense if you won't be keeping scraps of paper and big files. And yet we don't seem to be getting there. What's the resistance? What's between us and really having an electronic way to access our health care data?

ARNOLD: I think it's the consumer taking control. You know, now we have a smart phone, we have a common platform that we can develop to. But consider the hospital saying, you patient come to my portal and the health plans in, you as my member download my app. It's now about, you know, can you create a health profile on behalf of the person and use the technology to bring the stakeholders to that person's hand.

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Help guide those portal apps kill me every time. And like 17 is, oh my god. So if you talk about tech and health care, the first thing that come in to your mind is Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and J.P. Morgan.

ARNOLD: Yes.

STEEL: What do you think they're going to do for the industry?

ARNOLD: I think they're creating a catalyst for change. So, you know, all the incumbents have, you know, woke up and said, you know, we have to embrace technology, we have to embrace consumerism and we need to do things differently. I think the winner in this phase is whose going to be able to do manage the data, right.

So you have self-reported data, direct -- device driven, claims driven data, social determinants of health data and medical records. It's also going to come down to who can drive engagement, who can get the person to actually take that first step and take control of their health? And then lastly, there'll be awareness. You know, how do these new platforms make people feel?

WESTIN: When you tell like what kind of do (ph), we're pretty sensitive in general about our health care data. How are you going to guarantee that it's not going to be hacked or it's not going to be shared because we have a lot of digital companies right now who are under siege most recently Facebook.

ARNOLD: Well, I think in health, trust is paramount. So what we try to do in health care is try to build your health profile, somewhere to help linked in your business profile. But empower the consumer to own their data. So the health plan doesn't own the data, the PBM doesn't own the data. The health EMR system doesn't own the data. The person does. The person controls the permissions. So the same way they can turn on and off WiFi. They can exchange their medical records.

So trust is everything. But I think us breaking through and saying it's not the insurance company that owns the data, the person owns the data. If the person changes health plans, the data goes with them. If the person changes doctors, the data goes with them.

STEEL: But you've got to protect it. What do you think the threat is? We're going to see some federal regulation on big tech companies that would encompass something that you do.

ARNOLD: Well, I think, you know, outside of trust and transparency protecting the data is, you know, rule number one. And so we're embracing, you know, the best practices, you know, Blockchain's other technology is try to lock down the sensitive information. But it's a concern everybody has in the industry.

WESTIN: Could we guys actually help you as you delve your business as they were reassure the consumer is out there that actually there is some protection.

ARNOLD: I think so, I having standards that, you know, all of this fragmented data can talk to will help not only make the platforms more robust but, you know, build more consumer confidence.

STEEL: So what do you make of Mark Zuckerberg going to Capitol Hill over the next two days and facing Congress? So how do you think of this plays out in that industry?

ARNOLD: Well, you know, I think that, you know, people are so used to using these social platforms, it become such a daily way of life that the train someone has left the station. But I think it's all about transparency. I think people want to know, what are you doing with my data? And then people can make the choice, do they want to share that information or not. Are they willing to pray for premium services or is this going to be app supported? But I think all the facts are going to need to be on the table.

WESTIN: It's not just about convenience and actually it's also about cost over all. We've got a problem in this country as an increasing percentage of GDP is health care. Will your approach, if it becomes a standard will it bend the cost curve?

ARNOLD: It will bend the cost curve. And so we talk a lot about engagement, how does the application make you feel. But the key objectives are, how do you make people more self-aware about their health? How do you reduce risk escalation? How do you not overuse the emergency room? How do you optimize provider networks to get the right person to the right doctor? How do you help people at pharmacy stand which is out of control? You know, moving from branded drugs to generic drugs from retial to home delivery.

We can get the people on their smart phones at the right moment to help them make better decisions and how they control their health care which is ultimately going to reduce the cost.

STEEL: What's the biggest health care increase that you can take out? The biggest health care cost that you can help us take out?

ARNOLD: Well, I think, you know, there's a lot of areas because there's about eight key objectives that we work on. And at the first is making people more self-aware about their health in general. And we want to keep the people that are healthy, healthy right. So we don't want them to turn into chronic patients for us. Disease management and lifestyle management, I think you're going to see a revolution there.

It's almost going to be as this theory or Alexa which is your coach. So instead of somebody sitting on a call center trying to manage you remotely it's going to feel to that person like you're being coached 24/7, and so there's all of this data and A.I. and machine learning talk, starts to take shape of your health. You're going to be in control like you've never had before.

WESTIN: So finally, what's the biggest advantage you have because you're up against some pretty big players out there, big pharma, big PBMs, big health care organizations. How could you get an advantage?

ARNOLD: So we think ours is, you know, everybody talks about being disruptive. We think that want to be disruptive but not disenfranchised. So how do we work with the big health systems? How do we work with the big health plan and help them understand the consumer and bring their data to the palm in that person's hand. That's where we thrive today is working with these big organizations, helping them come into the consumerism age.

STEEL: All right, Jeff, great to catch up with you. Thank you so much. Jeff Arnold, CEO of Sharecare, help start WebMD disrupting the health care industry.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

November 6, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

JEFFEREY SOLOMON, CEO, COWEN

WESTIN: Welcome now Libby Cantrill, PIMCO's Head of Public Policy and Jeffrey Solomon Cowen CEO.

So, at the same time, if in fact the Republicans took both and that seems unlikely at this point. Could we have a lot more fiscal stimulus, could that make a difference actually in the markets?

SOLOMON: It would be tax cuts 2.0, I think you'd have a lot more stimulus. I do think that they do much more aggressive on things like trade policy. I do think that would happen, no question about it.

If the Republican state both it'll be business as usual and we continue to have the regular tour rollbacks, probably accelerates into 2020.

WESTIN: That's at the marco level, what about a specific sector take pharmaceuticals.

SOLOMON: Yes.

WESTIN: Because some people think that that someplace, that President Trump could be align with the Democrats on prescription drug prices.

SOLOMON: Yes, I think that's a big pharma, you have to be worried. If you have both houses to flip Democratic then I think you're what we'll see. One of the first things we'll see is we'll see drug pricing policy being discussed.

I still think it's going to be difficult to have a national drug rising policy, but there'll be a lot of hearings and big pharma executives will be dragged onto the floor. And I think there the President has had said pretty clearly he'd like to try do something.

I also think that pharma is ready for this, though. So let's be really clear. You've got a strategy, I think you're already starting to see industry began to take matters into its own hands and anticipation of something like this because it something that the industry has been talking about and wrestling with for a long time.

STEEL: Jeffrey, how are you position in for 2019? Like where do you think you're going to see the most activity? What's going to be the risk that you're looking for?

SOLOMON: So we still think there's some pretty big tailwinds behind to our discovery early stage, biotech and biopharma.

STEEL: Doesn't have to be biotech be anywhere --

urn:contentItem:5TNX-WXG1-JBHT-D0DF-00000-00Jeffrey Solomon is interviewed on BB TV2018-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:00ZLexisNexisJeffrey Solomon is interviewed on BB TVWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Welcome now Libby Cantrill, PIMCO's Head of Public Policy and Jeffrey Solomon Cowen CEO.

So, at the same time, if in fact the Republicans took both and that seems unlikely at this point. Could we have a lot more fiscal stimulus, could that make a difference actually in the markets?

JEFFEREY SOLOMON, CEO, COWEN: It would be tax cuts 2.0, I think you'd have a lot more stimulus. I do think that they do much more aggressive on things like trade policy. I do think that would happen, no question about it.

If the Republican state both it'll be business as usual and we continue to have the regular tour rollbacks, probably accelerates into 2020.

WESTIN: That's at the marco level, what about a specific sector take pharmaceuticals.

SOLOMON: Yes.

WESTIN: Because some people think that that someplace, that President Trump could be align with the Democrats on prescription drug prices.

SOLOMON: Yes, I think that's a big pharma, you have to be worried. If you have both houses to flip Democratic then I think you're what we'll see. One of the first things we'll see is we'll see drug pricing policy being discussed.

I still think it's going to be difficult to have a national drug rising policy, but there'll be a lot of hearings and big pharma executives will be dragged onto the floor. And I think there the President has had said pretty clearly he'd like to try do something.

I also think that pharma is ready for this, though. So let's be really clear. You've got a strategy, I think you're already starting to see industry began to take matters into its own hands and anticipation of something like this because it something that the industry has been talking about and wrestling with for a long time.

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Jeffrey, how are you position in for 2019? Like where do you think you're going to see the most activity? What's going to be the risk that you're looking for?

SOLOMON: So we still think there's some pretty big tailwinds behind to our discovery early stage, biotech and biopharma.

STEEL: Doesn't have to be biotech be anywhere --

SOLOMON: Yes. I'm saying even with the drug pricing juxtopition, I still think -- we think there's a lot innovation there to happen. Obviously we've bee very involve in the cannabis area and we actually think that if you look at a lot state houses and you look at a lot of the national polling.

I think there's a real push by the populist to figure out a way to have a national cannabis policy. And so, we would expect that at some point over the next two years that comes into play, certainly of both Houses with Democratic and you got a lot of statehouses that flip, there'll be a lot more of that.

WESTIN: So you think they actually could repeal the federal statute on cannabis?

SOLOMON: I think it's on the table. The Trump Administration hasn't exactly been hard line on this, I think that attorney general has been hard line on this but I'm not sure how much longer he stays around after the turn, and if that happens. There's a possibility. I would just say it opens it up and certainly if you watch with happening in Canada and you watch what happening in globally, this is a real business.

And so, we're continuing to think that over the next few years this plays out in a positive way.

STEEL: What do you think?

SOLOMON: I actually agree with that. I think that there's a big dichotomy between big banks and the rest of us. And I think if you're in the big bank game, you've got a lot more to worry about for a regulatory standpoint. I also think in big tech you have to worry about.

STEEL: I was just going to ask some more (ph) investigation.

SOLOMON: I think big tech has a lot to worry about both from Democrats and Republicans. And I would say regardless of the outcome here, I would expect to see more -- more investigation or more hearing around privacy and cyber security and all of these things that I think are impacting your average American.

And so, there I think Maxine Waters has been pretty clear that that something that she want's to do. And I think that they won't get a lot of push back from their Republicans on that either.

STEEL: Yes, all right.

WESTIN: So Jeffrey, at the same time we had Peter Mandelson saying that we had Nigel Farage over at London saying does (ph) agree of Brexit at all because they really caving in. What's your view on what's going to happen and how does it affect your business?

SOLOMON: So I think if you're running a business there, you've got to consider a hard Brexit. That's our default, right. If that happens, you have to be repaired for that. So, it's even harder probable lies it. But if it happens, if there's a one percent or two percent or five percent chance that it happens, you have to be prepared for that.

So, I think a lot of folks I know are really saying, listen we've got to prepare for a hard Brexit if it acts away from that, then we can adjust. But if you don't prepare for hard Brexit then I think you'll probably -- you're making be a big mistake.

STEEL: The people that you talk to in clients, how do they prepare for hard Brexit?

SOLOMON: Yes. A lot of it is moving people into areas where you can engage with the European Union. I think a lot of folks are looking at places where there's already financial infrastructure and support, a lot of people at Luxembourg, a lot of people are moving to the Republic of Ireland in places that are likely to end up in a much more favorable engagement.

And then you have to your London just be running as what any other place in the world. London and U.K. will be set of regimes and the U.E will be another and you'll have to have multiple offices in order to handle that.

STEEL: Because I feel like the narrative when Brexit happen was that, if it's a hard Brexit everything is off like the world is going to hell. It's going to be terrible. It'll be awful (ph). But with the way you're talking it seems like clients are already working towards some kind of hard Brexit and it's not breaking the system.

SOLOMON: I think that it depends on what business is you're in. So when we look at it. We cover Europe out of London. But is it really going to change. It'll be harder for people to move. We're still going to have most of our people in London and calling on European clients to say when we have people in New York calling European clients.

So that doesn't change much. But I think things like funding slows, if you're in the banking system there's a lot more challenges around that. We're on the side of that a little bit more. We're not really in the deposit taking mode or like that. If you're in that mode, I think it much more complicated.

LIBBY CANTRILL, HEAD OF PUBLIC POLICY FOR PIMCO: So yes, there's a lot of uncertainly. We won't we be surprise if the deadline is pushed out even further.

SOLOMON: Yes. But look what happen with MiFID II, that's a smaller microcosmos of what happened. So people put their head in the sand on MiFID II until it absolute certainly. And then all of sudden people scramble to figure out how to do MiFID II. And the regulators ultimately, backing away in terms of implementation and penalties and things like that so that people could get their act together.

But for a long time people just ignore it like it wasn't going to happen. And so, again I don't want to equate the two because I think Brexit has much more complicated thing in MiFID II. But we all adjusted to MiFID II and we had business plans and contingencies ready to go.

And so, I think might be that was a dry run.

STEEL: Well, there's a narrative in the market though that it is enough financial pressure on the U.K. or the E.U. to actually make a deal. We've heard the same thing with Italy in terms of their budget deficit to your point. You're not going to make a deal into your fear literally in the fire.

So, that is true. And I think if you look at what's really driving Brexit, it's really not economic in many instances. It's immigration and social. And these things ebb and flow, the impetus may be to bring about Brexit and to get the vote out a couple of years ago was really at the height of this immigration crisis that was happening, this migration was happening for the Middle East.

Like, is that moderates and people adjust to the new normal, does Britain take a step back and say well, maybe it's not as bad as we thought it was going to be and I think the border with Ireland is the really -- there are not a lot of people who want to go back to a hard border with Ireland.

And so, I'm taking a look at the social aspects of this and try to take my cues there rather than economic because let's acknowledge it. It is way better for Britain and way better in the E.U.

STEEL: Right.

SOLOMON: From economic standpoint if things stay as is. It just the social issues and how can you bridge that gap.

STEEL: So we're going to leave it there. And much come with Libby Cantrill with PIMCO and Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

STEEL: And look at that. Look who we have, it so happen that we have Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen, so in pivoting real quickly up is SKIP McGee there (ph). What can opportunity set did you see there?

SOLOMON: Well, I think there's a tremendous amount of opportunity of opportunity both to provide financial, advice in financing. And I think this is -- what were seeing here is that, for us to try to recreate the kind of financial advice that Skip McGee and Chris Winchenbaugh team can do is just -- it would be really hard for us to do that. They're excellent at it.

And we're excellent into capital raising and financing and resurge and sales and trading. And you're not going to create that infrastructure. So for us, there's a national place where we can align with them, to really address the total needs of client in that space.

And it's a great cultural fit because Skip and Chris teams spent a lot of time with Larry Wieseneck who's our Co-President. There's a great cultural. Today, there so were co-pitching and doing things where we can work collectively to solve problems for clients across financing and strategic advice. So, it just makes sense to do that.

STEEL: Is that mean that you see more M&A going forward for the space? Debt is still a concern for a lot of them. Is it M&A?

SOLOMON: Yes, I think it could be M&A and I think it can be refinancing. I think this is -- like a lot of businesses that are capital intention, there's always capital raising going on. And I think if you're a manager in that business, you go to look at strategic as well as financing concurrently.

And so, we'll leave it right a full range of services collectively between both of our organization and of course, most of those folks want research coverage and sales and trading and support the after market if you're public.

And that something that we have an excellent footprint in already and we can bring that to bear for a lot of clients.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jeffrey, as we're resetting our economic relationship, China on its own is resetting its economy. I mean, you see a slow down in GDP growth. They were trying to deleverage. They can't quite afford to do that. What is the risk to global growth overall?

SOLOMON: I actually think it's pretty significant. When you got the two large economist at odds at one another, that's generally not good for global GDP growth. I actually think, China is struggling with meeting domestically and it's one belt one road strategy.

If you think about the amount of capital that it spent in Eastern Europe for example, I don't know how that sustainable if the home economy is really working that well. It turns out that whether you're a sort of plan capital economy or market capital economy, either one.

It's hard to spend money both domestically to fix domestic problems and invest globally to protect your interest. So, that's what the U.S. has been facing over the last view decades, certainly after the financial crisis. It's harder for us to spend money abroad to do Pax Americana when we've got fundamental issues here.

I think China has the same issues because at the end of the day you got to take care of the home front first before you can think about the rest of the world.

WESTIN: At the same time China again and again has over performed, I mean done better than what we thought they would do.

SOLOMON: Or so they like you to think. I mean I think it's really hard to know.

STEEL: But they do come in and do back stopping. I mean, they made money available to small and medium size businesses. I mean, they use to pop up SOEs like there in there.

SOLOMON: They are in there, just like we're in there with our government propping up our businesses. We do this. It's funny to me, when we had a financial crisis. We propped up steel. We propped up autos. We propped up the financial system like we did it because we needed to.

And they will do it because they may need to. So, I actually don't think there's a tremendous amount of out difference between the way that we approach our businesses in times of stress and the way that they approach their businesses in times of economic stress.

I actually I think it's actually pretty similar.

STEEL: So what does mean for actually business. Like if you ask anyone two years ago in investment banking. They would say cross board or M&A, China buying companies elsewhere whether in Europe and the U.S. was the thing.

SOLOMON: Yes. I was. So we have personal -- first hand experiences as we have a deal to have sell 20 percent of our company to a Chinese private investors, a private company and it was one of the largest oil importers in refiners.

We did it not because we needed the money. We did it because we really thought it was going to give us a window and in doing cross boarder transaction of financing in China with the strategic partner. Today, we can't even find that guy just to be really clear.

Like, they're literally dismantling that his empire, which is huge amounts of money was spent in Eastern Europe with a big, all the old Eastern Bloc nations that part of the one belt, one road strategy. There's a lot of capital was spent there like, I just will say like what we heard 18 months ago and what's actually happening are two very different things.

And we're super thankful that ultimately we didn't do that deal. Because I guess I'm not sure how we would have been able to approach doing business in China given really the bipolar nature of it.

CANTRILL: So it's not to say that they necessarily won't boycott American companies but at this point it's been interesting that they have necessary pulled on that lever yet.

SOLOMON: Yes. I don't disagree with that. I think it's better if we have a more friendly engagement with China, particularly given our current account deficit, right. I think we have to figure out how to create the new balance.

And I've always said that I think tariff is a blunt force instrument to bring people to the table. I think if you're the Trump administration, you're trying to reset the table for global trade. Tariff is a way to bring everybody to the table.

WESTIN: Yes.

SOLOMON: That is a strategy in and of itself. But let's face it. If we can figure out what the new normal looks like and create better trade and balance between the two countries, everybody wins. How do we get from here to there? That's the big question.

WESTIN: If we can, as (INAUDIBLE) phrase there. OK. Libby Cantrill of PIMCO and Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen, thank so much for being with us.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Jeffrey Solomon discusses global economics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Welcome now Libby Cantrill, PIMCO's Head of Public Policy and Jeffrey Solomon Cowen CEO.

So, at the same time, if in fact the Republicans took both and that seems unlikely at this point. Could we have a lot more fiscal stimulus, could that make a difference actually in the markets?

JEFFEREY SOLOMON, CEO, COWEN: It would be tax cuts 2.0, I think you'd have a lot more stimulus. I do think that they do much more aggressive on things like trade policy. I do think that would happen, no question about it.

If the Republican state both it'll be business as usual and we continue to have the regular tour rollbacks, probably accelerates into 2020.

WESTIN: That's at the marco level, what about a specific sector take pharmaceuticals.

SOLOMON: Yes.

WESTIN: Because some people think that that someplace, that President Trump could be align with the Democrats on prescription drug prices.

SOLOMON: Yes, I think that's a big pharma, you have to be worried. If you have both houses to flip Democratic then I think you're what we'll see. One of the first things we'll see is we'll see drug pricing policy being discussed.

I still think it's going to be difficult to have a national drug rising policy, but there'll be a lot of hearings and big pharma executives will be dragged onto the floor. And I think there the President has had said pretty clearly he'd like to try do something.

I also think that pharma is ready for this, though. So let's be really clear. You've got a strategy, I think you're already starting to see industry began to take matters into its own hands and anticipation of something like this because it something that the industry has been talking about and wrestling with for a long time.

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Jeffrey, how are you position in for 2019? Like where do you think you're going to see the most activity? What's going to be the risk that you're looking for?

SOLOMON: So we still think there's some pretty big tailwinds behind to our discovery early stage, biotech and biopharma.

STEEL: Doesn't have to be biotech be anywhere --

SOLOMON: Yes. I'm saying even with the drug pricing juxtopition, I still think -- we think there's a lot innovation there to happen. Obviously we've bee very involve in the cannabis area and we actually think that if you look at a lot state houses and you look at a lot of the national polling.

I think there's a real push by the populist to figure out a way to have a national cannabis policy. And so, we would expect that at some point over the next two years that comes into play, certainly of both Houses with Democratic and you got a lot of statehouses that flip, there'll be a lot more of that.

WESTIN: So you think they actually could repeal the federal statute on cannabis?

SOLOMON: I think it's on the table. The Trump Administration hasn't exactly been hard line on this, I think that attorney general has been hard line on this but I'm not sure how much longer he stays around after the turn, and if that happens. There's a possibility. I would just say it opens it up and certainly if you watch with happening in Canada and you watch what happening in globally, this is a real business.

And so, we're continuing to think that over the next few years this plays out in a positive way.

STEEL: What do you think?

SOLOMON: I actually agree with that. I think that there's a big dichotomy between big banks and the rest of us. And I think if you're in the big bank game, you've got a lot more to worry about for a regulatory standpoint. I also think in big tech you have to worry about.

STEEL: I was just going to ask some more (ph) investigation.

SOLOMON: I think big tech has a lot to worry about both from Democrats and Republicans. And I would say regardless of the outcome here, I would expect to see more -- more investigation or more hearing around privacy and cyber security and all of these things that I think are impacting your average American.

And so, there I think Maxine Waters has been pretty clear that that something that she want's to do. And I think that they won't get a lot of push back from their Republicans on that either.

STEEL: Yes, all right.

WESTIN: So Jeffrey, at the same time we had Peter Mandelson saying that we had Nigel Farage over at London saying does (ph) agree of Brexit at all because they really caving in. What's your view on what's going to happen and how does it affect your business?

SOLOMON: So I think if you're running a business there, you've got to consider a hard Brexit. That's our default, right. If that happens, you have to be repaired for that. So, it's even harder probable lies it. But if it happens, if there's a one percent or two percent or five percent chance that it happens, you have to be prepared for that.

So, I think a lot of folks I know are really saying, listen we've got to prepare for a hard Brexit if it acts away from that, then we can adjust. But if you don't prepare for hard Brexit then I think you'll probably -- you're making be a big mistake.

STEEL: The people that you talk to in clients, how do they prepare for hard Brexit?

SOLOMON: Yes. A lot of it is moving people into areas where you can engage with the European Union. I think a lot of folks are looking at places where there's already financial infrastructure and support, a lot of people at Luxembourg, a lot of people are moving to the Republic of Ireland in places that are likely to end up in a much more favorable engagement.

And then you have to your London just be running as what any other place in the world. London and U.K. will be set of regimes and the U.E will be another and you'll have to have multiple offices in order to handle that.

STEEL: Because I feel like the narrative when Brexit happen was that, if it's a hard Brexit everything is off like the world is going to hell. It's going to be terrible. It'll be awful (ph). But with the way you're talking it seems like clients are already working towards some kind of hard Brexit and it's not breaking the system.

SOLOMON: I think that it depends on what business is you're in. So when we look at it. We cover Europe out of London. But is it really going to change. It'll be harder for people to move. We're still going to have most of our people in London and calling on European clients to say when we have people in New York calling European clients.

So that doesn't change much. But I think things like funding slows, if you're in the banking system there's a lot more challenges around that. We're on the side of that a little bit more. We're not really in the deposit taking mode or like that. If you're in that mode, I think it much more complicated.

LIBBY CANTRILL, HEAD OF PUBLIC POLICY FOR PIMCO: So yes, there's a lot of uncertainly. We won't we be surprise if the deadline is pushed out even further.

SOLOMON: Yes. But look what happen with MiFID II, that's a smaller microcosmos of what happened. So people put their head in the sand on MiFID II until it absolute certainly. And then all of sudden people scramble to figure out how to do MiFID II. And the regulators ultimately, backing away in terms of implementation and penalties and things like that so that people could get their act together.

But for a long time people just ignore it like it wasn't going to happen. And so, again I don't want to equate the two because I think Brexit has much more complicated thing in MiFID II. But we all adjusted to MiFID II and we had business plans and contingencies ready to go.

And so, I think might be that was a dry run.

STEEL: Well, there's a narrative in the market though that it is enough financial pressure on the U.K. or the E.U. to actually make a deal. We've heard the same thing with Italy in terms of their budget deficit to your point. You're not going to make a deal into your fear literally in the fire.

So, that is true. And I think if you look at what's really driving Brexit, it's really not economic in many instances. It's immigration and social. And these things ebb and flow, the impetus may be to bring about Brexit and to get the vote out a couple of years ago was really at the height of this immigration crisis that was happening, this migration was happening for the Middle East.

Like, is that moderates and people adjust to the new normal, does Britain take a step back and say well, maybe it's not as bad as we thought it was going to be and I think the border with Ireland is the really -- there are not a lot of people who want to go back to a hard border with Ireland.

And so, I'm taking a look at the social aspects of this and try to take my cues there rather than economic because let's acknowledge it. It is way better for Britain and way better in the E.U.

STEEL: Right.

SOLOMON: From economic standpoint if things stay as is. It just the social issues and how can you bridge that gap.

STEEL: So we're going to leave it there. And much come with Libby Cantrill with PIMCO and Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

STEEL: And look at that. Look who we have, it so happen that we have Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen, so in pivoting real quickly up is SKIP McGee there (ph). What can opportunity set did you see there?

SOLOMON: Well, I think there's a tremendous amount of opportunity of opportunity both to provide financial, advice in financing. And I think this is -- what were seeing here is that, for us to try to recreate the kind of financial advice that Skip McGee and Chris Winchenbaugh team can do is just -- it would be really hard for us to do that. They're excellent at it.

And we're excellent into capital raising and financing and resurge and sales and trading. And you're not going to create that infrastructure. So for us, there's a national place where we can align with them, to really address the total needs of client in that space.

And it's a great cultural fit because Skip and Chris teams spent a lot of time with Larry Wieseneck who's our Co-President. There's a great cultural. Today, there so were co-pitching and doing things where we can work collectively to solve problems for clients across financing and strategic advice. So, it just makes sense to do that.

STEEL: Is that mean that you see more M&A going forward for the space? Debt is still a concern for a lot of them. Is it M&A?

SOLOMON: Yes, I think it could be M&A and I think it can be refinancing. I think this is -- like a lot of businesses that are capital intention, there's always capital raising going on. And I think if you're a manager in that business, you go to look at strategic as well as financing concurrently.

And so, we'll leave it right a full range of services collectively between both of our organization and of course, most of those folks want research coverage and sales and trading and support the after market if you're public.

And that something that we have an excellent footprint in already and we can bring that to bear for a lot of clients.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jeffrey, as we're resetting our economic relationship, China on its own is resetting its economy. I mean, you see a slow down in GDP growth. They were trying to deleverage. They can't quite afford to do that. What is the risk to global growth overall?

SOLOMON: I actually think it's pretty significant. When you got the two large economist at odds at one another, that's generally not good for global GDP growth. I actually think, China is struggling with meeting domestically and it's one belt one road strategy.

If you think about the amount of capital that it spent in Eastern Europe for example, I don't know how that sustainable if the home economy is really working that well. It turns out that whether you're a sort of plan capital economy or market capital economy, either one.

It's hard to spend money both domestically to fix domestic problems and invest globally to protect your interest. So, that's what the U.S. has been facing over the last view decades, certainly after the financial crisis. It's harder for us to spend money abroad to do Pax Americana when we've got fundamental issues here.

I think China has the same issues because at the end of the day you got to take care of the home front first before you can think about the rest of the world.

WESTIN: At the same time China again and again has over performed, I mean done better than what we thought they would do.

SOLOMON: Or so they like you to think. I mean I think it's really hard to know.

STEEL: But they do come in and do back stopping. I mean, they made money available to small and medium size businesses. I mean, they use to pop up SOEs like there in there.

SOLOMON: They are in there, just like we're in there with our government propping up our businesses. We do this. It's funny to me, when we had a financial crisis. We propped up steel. We propped up autos. We propped up the financial system like we did it because we needed to.

And they will do it because they may need to. So, I actually don't think there's a tremendous amount of out difference between the way that we approach our businesses in times of stress and the way that they approach their businesses in times of economic stress.

I actually I think it's actually pretty similar.

STEEL: So what does mean for actually business. Like if you ask anyone two years ago in investment banking. They would say cross board or M&A, China buying companies elsewhere whether in Europe and the U.S. was the thing.

SOLOMON: Yes. I was. So we have personal -- first hand experiences as we have a deal to have sell 20 percent of our company to a Chinese private investors, a private company and it was one of the largest oil importers in refiners.

We did it not because we needed the money. We did it because we really thought it was going to give us a window and in doing cross boarder transaction of financing in China with the strategic partner. Today, we can't even find that guy just to be really clear.

Like, they're literally dismantling that his empire, which is huge amounts of money was spent in Eastern Europe with a big, all the old Eastern Bloc nations that part of the one belt, one road strategy. There's a lot of capital was spent there like, I just will say like what we heard 18 months ago and what's actually happening are two very different things.

And we're super thankful that ultimately we didn't do that deal. Because I guess I'm not sure how we would have been able to approach doing business in China given really the bipolar nature of it.

CANTRILL: So it's not to say that they necessarily won't boycott American companies but at this point it's been interesting that they have necessary pulled on that lever yet.

SOLOMON: Yes. I don't disagree with that. I think it's better if we have a more friendly engagement with China, particularly given our current account deficit, right. I think we have to figure out how to create the new balance.

And I've always said that I think tariff is a blunt force instrument to bring people to the table. I think if you're the Trump administration, you're trying to reset the table for global trade. Tariff is a way to bring everybody to the table.

WESTIN: Yes.

SOLOMON: That is a strategy in and of itself. But let's face it. If we can figure out what the new normal looks like and create better trade and balance between the two countries, everybody wins. How do we get from here to there? That's the big question.

WESTIN: If we can, as (INAUDIBLE) phrase there. OK. Libby Cantrill of PIMCO and Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen, thank so much for being with us.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5TNX-WXG1-JBHT-D0CN-00000-00Jeffrey Solomon is interviewed on BB TV2018-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:00ZLexisNexisJeffrey Solomon is interviewed on BB TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Welcome now Libby Cantrill, PIMCO's Head of Public Policy and Jeffrey Solomon Cowen CEO.

So, at the same time, if in fact the Republicans took both and that seems unlikely at this point. Could we have a lot more fiscal stimulus, could that make a difference actually in the markets?

JEFFEREY SOLOMON, CEO, COWEN: It would be tax cuts 2.0, I think you'd have a lot more stimulus. I do think that they do much more aggressive on things like trade policy. I do think that would happen, no question about it.

If the Republican state both it'll be business as usual and we continue to have the regular tour rollbacks, probably accelerates into 2020.

WESTIN: That's at the marco level, what about a specific sector take pharmaceuticals.

SOLOMON: Yes.

WESTIN: Because some people think that that someplace, that President Trump could be align with the Democrats on prescription drug prices.

SOLOMON: Yes, I think that's a big pharma, you have to be worried. If you have both houses to flip Democratic then I think you're what we'll see. One of the first things we'll see is we'll see drug pricing policy being discussed.

I still think it's going to be difficult to have a national drug rising policy, but there'll be a lot of hearings and big pharma executives will be dragged onto the floor. And I think there the President has had said pretty clearly he'd like to try do something.

I also think that pharma is ready for this, though. So let's be really clear. You've got a strategy, I think you're already starting to see industry began to take matters into its own hands and anticipation of something like this because it something that the industry has been talking about and wrestling with for a long time.

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Jeffrey, how are you position in for 2019? Like where do you think you're going to see the most activity? What's going to be the risk that you're looking for?

SOLOMON: So we still think there's some pretty big tailwinds behind to our discovery early stage, biotech and biopharma.

STEEL: Doesn't have to be biotech be anywhere --

SOLOMON: Yes. I'm saying even with the drug pricing juxtopition, I still think -- we think there's a lot innovation there to happen. Obviously we've bee very involve in the cannabis area and we actually think that if you look at a lot state houses and you look at a lot of the national polling.

I think there's a real push by the populist to figure out a way to have a national cannabis policy. And so, we would expect that at some point over the next two years that comes into play, certainly of both Houses with Democratic and you got a lot of statehouses that flip, there'll be a lot more of that.

WESTIN: So you think they actually could repeal the federal statute on cannabis?

SOLOMON: I think it's on the table. The Trump Administration hasn't exactly been hard line on this, I think that attorney general has been hard line on this but I'm not sure how much longer he stays around after the turn, and if that happens. There's a possibility. I would just say it opens it up and certainly if you watch with happening in Canada and you watch what happening in globally, this is a real business.

And so, we're continuing to think that over the next few years this plays out in a positive way.

STEEL: What do you think?

SOLOMON: I actually agree with that. I think that there's a big dichotomy between big banks and the rest of us. And I think if you're in the big bank game, you've got a lot more to worry about for a regulatory standpoint. I also think in big tech you have to worry about.

STEEL: I was just going to ask some more (ph) investigation.

SOLOMON: I think big tech has a lot to worry about both from Democrats and Republicans. And I would say regardless of the outcome here, I would expect to see more -- more investigation or more hearing around privacy and cyber security and all of these things that I think are impacting your average American.

And so, there I think Maxine Waters has been pretty clear that that something that she want's to do. And I think that they won't get a lot of push back from their Republicans on that either.

STEEL: Yes, all right.

WESTIN: So Jeffrey, at the same time we had Peter Mandelson saying that we had Nigel Farage over at London saying does (ph) agree of Brexit at all because they really caving in. What's your view on what's going to happen and how does it affect your business?

SOLOMON: So I think if you're running a business there, you've got to consider a hard Brexit. That's our default, right. If that happens, you have to be repaired for that. So, it's even harder probable lies it. But if it happens, if there's a one percent or two percent or five percent chance that it happens, you have to be prepared for that.

So, I think a lot of folks I know are really saying, listen we've got to prepare for a hard Brexit if it acts away from that, then we can adjust. But if you don't prepare for hard Brexit then I think you'll probably -- you're making be a big mistake.

STEEL: The people that you talk to in clients, how do they prepare for hard Brexit?

SOLOMON: Yes. A lot of it is moving people into areas where you can engage with the European Union. I think a lot of folks are looking at places where there's already financial infrastructure and support, a lot of people at Luxembourg, a lot of people are moving to the Republic of Ireland in places that are likely to end up in a much more favorable engagement.

And then you have to your London just be running as what any other place in the world. London and U.K. will be set of regimes and the U.E will be another and you'll have to have multiple offices in order to handle that.

STEEL: Because I feel like the narrative when Brexit happen was that, if it's a hard Brexit everything is off like the world is going to hell. It's going to be terrible. It'll be awful (ph). But with the way you're talking it seems like clients are already working towards some kind of hard Brexit and it's not breaking the system.

SOLOMON: I think that it depends on what business is you're in. So when we look at it. We cover Europe out of London. But is it really going to change. It'll be harder for people to move. We're still going to have most of our people in London and calling on European clients to say when we have people in New York calling European clients.

So that doesn't change much. But I think things like funding slows, if you're in the banking system there's a lot more challenges around that. We're on the side of that a little bit more. We're not really in the deposit taking mode or like that. If you're in that mode, I think it much more complicated.

LIBBY CANTRILL, HEAD OF PUBLIC POLICY FOR PIMCO: So yes, there's a lot of uncertainly. We won't we be surprise if the deadline is pushed out even further.

SOLOMON: Yes. But look what happen with MiFID II, that's a smaller microcosmos of what happened. So people put their head in the sand on MiFID II until it absolute certainly. And then all of sudden people scramble to figure out how to do MiFID II. And the regulators ultimately, backing away in terms of implementation and penalties and things like that so that people could get their act together.

But for a long time people just ignore it like it wasn't going to happen. And so, again I don't want to equate the two because I think Brexit has much more complicated thing in MiFID II. But we all adjusted to MiFID II and we had business plans and contingencies ready to go.

And so, I think might be that was a dry run.

STEEL: Well, there's a narrative in the market though that it is enough financial pressure on the U.K. or the E.U. to actually make a deal. We've heard the same thing with Italy in terms of their budget deficit to your point. You're not going to make a deal into your fear literally in the fire.

So, that is true. And I think if you look at what's really driving Brexit, it's really not economic in many instances. It's immigration and social. And these things ebb and flow, the impetus may be to bring about Brexit and to get the vote out a couple of years ago was really at the height of this immigration crisis that was happening, this migration was happening for the Middle East.

Like, is that moderates and people adjust to the new normal, does Britain take a step back and say well, maybe it's not as bad as we thought it was going to be and I think the border with Ireland is the really -- there are not a lot of people who want to go back to a hard border with Ireland.

And so, I'm taking a look at the social aspects of this and try to take my cues there rather than economic because let's acknowledge it. It is way better for Britain and way better in the E.U.

STEEL: Right.

SOLOMON: From economic standpoint if things stay as is. It just the social issues and how can you bridge that gap.

STEEL: So we're going to leave it there. And much come with Libby Cantrill with PIMCO and Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

STEEL: And look at that. Look who we have, it so happen that we have Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen, so in pivoting real quickly up is SKIP McGee there (ph). What can opportunity set did you see there?

SOLOMON: Well, I think there's a tremendous amount of opportunity of opportunity both to provide financial, advice in financing. And I think this is -- what were seeing here is that, for us to try to recreate the kind of financial advice that Skip McGee and Chris Winchenbaugh team can do is just -- it would be really hard for us to do that. They're excellent at it.

And we're excellent into capital raising and financing and resurge and sales and trading. And you're not going to create that infrastructure. So for us, there's a national place where we can align with them, to really address the total needs of client in that space.

And it's a great cultural fit because Skip and Chris teams spent a lot of time with Larry Wieseneck who's our Co-President. There's a great cultural. Today, there so were co-pitching and doing things where we can work collectively to solve problems for clients across financing and strategic advice. So, it just makes sense to do that.

STEEL: Is that mean that you see more M&A going forward for the space? Debt is still a concern for a lot of them. Is it M&A?

SOLOMON: Yes, I think it could be M&A and I think it can be refinancing. I think this is -- like a lot of businesses that are capital intention, there's always capital raising going on. And I think if you're a manager in that business, you go to look at strategic as well as financing concurrently.

And so, we'll leave it right a full range of services collectively between both of our organization and of course, most of those folks want research coverage and sales and trading and support the after market if you're public.

And that something that we have an excellent footprint in already and we can bring that to bear for a lot of clients.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jeffrey, as we're resetting our economic relationship, China on its own is resetting its economy. I mean, you see a slow down in GDP growth. They were trying to deleverage. They can't quite afford to do that. What is the risk to global growth overall?

SOLOMON: I actually think it's pretty significant. When you got the two large economist at odds at one another, that's generally not good for global GDP growth. I actually think, China is struggling with meeting domestically and it's one belt one road strategy.

If you think about the amount of capital that it spent in Eastern Europe for example, I don't know how that sustainable if the home economy is really working that well. It turns out that whether you're a sort of plan capital economy or market capital economy, either one.

It's hard to spend money both domestically to fix domestic problems and invest globally to protect your interest. So, that's what the U.S. has been facing over the last view decades, certainly after the financial crisis. It's harder for us to spend money abroad to do Pax Americana when we've got fundamental issues here.

I think China has the same issues because at the end of the day you got to take care of the home front first before you can think about the rest of the world.

WESTIN: At the same time China again and again has over performed, I mean done better than what we thought they would do.

SOLOMON: Or so they like you to think. I mean I think it's really hard to know.

STEEL: But they do come in and do back stopping. I mean, they made money available to small and medium size businesses. I mean, they use to pop up SOEs like there in there.

SOLOMON: They are in there, just like we're in there with our government propping up our businesses. We do this. It's funny to me, when we had a financial crisis. We propped up steel. We propped up autos. We propped up the financial system like we did it because we needed to.

And they will do it because they may need to. So, I actually don't think there's a tremendous amount of out difference between the way that we approach our businesses in times of stress and the way that they approach their businesses in times of economic stress.

I actually I think it's actually pretty similar.

STEEL: So what does mean for actually business. Like if you ask anyone two years ago in investment banking. They would say cross board or M&A, China buying companies elsewhere whether in Europe and the U.S. was the thing.

SOLOMON: Yes. I was. So we have personal -- first hand experiences as we have a deal to have sell 20 percent of our company to a Chinese private investors, a private company and it was one of the largest oil importers in refiners.

We did it not because we needed the money. We did it because we really thought it was going to give us a window and in doing cross boarder transaction of financing in China with the strategic partner. Today, we can't even find that guy just to be really clear.

Like, they're literally dismantling that his empire, which is huge amounts of money was spent in Eastern Europe with a big, all the old Eastern Bloc nations that part of the one belt, one road strategy. There's a lot of capital was spent there like, I just will say like what we heard 18 months ago and what's actually happening are two very different things.

And we're super thankful that ultimately we didn't do that deal. Because I guess I'm not sure how we would have been able to approach doing business in China given really the bipolar nature of it.

CANTRILL: So it's not to say that they necessarily won't boycott American companies but at this point it's been interesting that they have necessary pulled on that lever yet.

SOLOMON: Yes. I don't disagree with that. I think it's better if we have a more friendly engagement with China, particularly given our current account deficit, right. I think we have to figure out how to create the new balance.

And I've always said that I think tariff is a blunt force instrument to bring people to the table. I think if you're the Trump administration, you're trying to reset the table for global trade. Tariff is a way to bring everybody to the table.

WESTIN: Yes.

SOLOMON: That is a strategy in and of itself. But let's face it. If we can figure out what the new normal looks like and create better trade and balance between the two countries, everybody wins. How do we get from here to there? That's the big question.

WESTIN: If we can, as (INAUDIBLE) phrase there. OK. Libby Cantrill of PIMCO and Jeffrey Solomon of Cowen, thank so much for being with us.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Sep 05, 2018( Mediaite: http://www.mediaite.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ; The Department of Justice has released a statement from Jeff Sessions, saying he's going to call on state attorneys general from around the country this month to hold a meeting with him about the impact of social media. The Sessions announcement appears to be a response to the Senate Intel Committee's hearing today with officials from Twitter and Facebook.

Much of the conversation gravitated around foreign disinformation campaigns across social media, as well as big tech's alleged bias against right-wing viewpoints. From the DOJ's memo:'The Attorney General has convened a meeting with a number of state attorneys general this month to discuss a growing concern that these companies may be hurting competition ...tentionally stifling the free exchange of ideas on their platforms.' urn:contentItem:5SY0-TGV1-JBG3-61PM-00000-00Jeff Sessions, Trade War, Denmark: Your Thursday Briefing;Europe Edition2018-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:00ZLexisNexisBRIEFINGJeff Sessions, Trade War, Denmark: Your Thursday BriefingEurope EditionRemy Tumin

Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

Good morning. An extraordinary request in Washington, a ban on veils in Denmark and the decade that almost stopped climate change.

Here’s the latest:

“Stop this Rigged Witch Hunt right now.”

On Twitter, President Trump took the extraordinary step of asking Jeff Sessions, the attorney general, to end the special counsel’s investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election and possible Russian links to his campaign.

The tweet immediately raised questions about whether Mr. Trump was trying to obstruct justice. But his lawyers said he was expressing an opinion, not issuing an order.

Mr. Trump is also ratcheting up his trade war with China. The administration is considering raising tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese products to 25 percent — not the 10 percent previously indicated — in a bid to bring Beijing back to the bargaining table.

_____

“My clothes, my choice.”

Protesters took to the streets in Copenhagen on Wednesday as Denmark’s ban on wearing face veils in public went into effect. Carrying signs with phrases like “Fingers away from my niqab,” women wearing the traditional Muslim veil were joined by dozens of supporters wearing makeshift coverings across their faces.

The law, passed in May, does not specifically mention Muslim dress, but protesters say Muslim women are the intended target.

Denmark follows Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Bulgaria and parts of Switzerland, which have all moved to either ban or restrict the veil.

_____

There’s been an impressive amount of non-Brexit news from Britain.

A company called Beyond, which offers funeral price comparisons, says it wanted to start a national conversation about death by creating edgy ads, like the one above. But regulators rejected them, saying they were likely to cause offense.

Over at the U.S. Embassy in London, items of little historical value are on the auction block: 1,200 rolls of toilet paper, plastic chairs and a Sony camera (but please don’t ask where the charger is). The embassy, which in January moved from Grosvenor Square in central London to a high-tech glass building near the River Thames, is getting rid of surplus property.

And the Freemasons of England are welcoming transgender members for the first time. Male members who have transitioned to female can stay, and transgender men can join the traditionally all-male group.

_____

Losing Earth.

The Times Magazine this week is devoted to the period from 1979 to 1989, “the decade we almost stopped climate change.”

The writer Nathaniel Rich traces how humankind first came to a broad understanding of the causes and dangers of climate change. Mauritania, above, is one of the regions in Africa most vulnerable to recurrent drought.

The expansive narrative covers the efforts of a small group of American scientists, activists and politicians, and explains how thoroughly they grasped the problem and how agonizingly close they came to solving it.

Business

Condé Nast, the company behind Vogue, Vanity Fair and The New Yorker, plans to put three of its 14 magazines up for sale. The aforementioned marquee titles are safe. Vogue’s editor in chief, Anna Wintour, above, will remain with the company “indefinitely.”

The chairman and chief executive of ArcelorMittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, is the rare business leader who applauds President Trump’s protectionist approach to trade. The company’s profit rose to $1.9 billion in the second quarter.

Big tech: strong as ever. Don’t let Facebook’s stock crash fool you, our tech columnist writes: The “frightful five” — Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft — are still on their way to dominating the future.

Here’s a snapshot of global markets.

In the News

The decades-old Kashmir war, a territorial dispute between India and Pakistan, has become a bitterly personal, and mostly local, insurgency. [The New York Times]

Video of a young woman in Paris being struck on the head after chastising a man she said harassed her has drawn new attention to the #MeToo movement in France. [The New York Times]

The White House is considering a second sharp reduction in the number of refugees who can be resettled in the United States. One proposal cuts more than 40 percent from this year’s limit. [The New York Times]

At least three people were killed during protests in Zimbabwe’s capital, as demonstrators called the country’s elections a sham and armed soldiers swept the streets. [The New York Times]

Relatives of two people who died in wildfires outside Athens last month are suing Greek officials, alleging negligence in their response to Greece’s deadliest blaze in a decade. [Associated Press]

Three national treasures of Sweden — two royal crowns and an orb from the 17th century — were stolen in an audacious midday theft from a cathedral near Stockholm. The thieves escaped by speedboat. [The New York Times]

Smarter Living

Tips for a more fulfilling life.

A smarter way to think about financial decisions.

That buyout offer sounds tempting. But it’s risky.

Recipe of the day: Chicken salad can get boring, so add miso and sesame into the mix.

Noteworthy

Clara Lemlich Shavelson inspired what became known as the Uprising of the 20,000 to improve working conditions for female garment workers, above. She galvanized working-class women to fight for suffrage and battled for tenants’ rights. But she never received a proper obituary in the Times, until now.

We sat down with the French film star Vincent Cassel, who sped-talk his way through a conversation about sex, Gallic masculinity and his latest film, “Gauguin: Voyage to Tahiti.” The interview lasted 24 minutes.

Between April and September, tiny green worms emerge along the coasts of England, Wales, France and the Channel Islands, and they form swirling masses. But nobody is sure why.

Back Story

President Trump has so far made two Supreme Court nominations, which is about average. But some presidents didn’t get to name anyone to the court.

No vacancies came up while Jimmy Carter was president from 1977 to 1981 (although he reportedly pressured Justice Thurgood Marshall to resign after losing the 1980 election to Ronald Reagan). Critics of the Supreme Court have pointed to Mr. Carter’s lack of nominees as a reason to   impose term limits on the nine justices.

But Mr. Carter put his own stamp on the federal bench, appointing more minority (57) and female (41) judges than all presidents before him combined. Others have   followed his example.

Mr. Carter also holds the record for most federal judges appointed in a single term (262).

The three other presidents with no Supreme Court appointments did not serve full terms. They were William Henry Harrison, who died of pneumonia in 1841, a month after giving a two-hour inaugural address without a coat; Zachary Taylor, who died under   disputed circumstances in 1850 after 16 months in office; and Andrew Johnson, who became president in 1865 after Abraham Lincoln’s assassination.

Johnson was so thoroughly disliked by members of Congress that they passed a bill reducing the size of the Supreme Court rather than confirm his sole nominee.

Jennifer Jett wrote today’s Back Story.

_____
